Rationale and evidence
It is estimated that 41.8% of pregnant women worldwide are anaemic ( 177). At least half of this 
anaemia burden is assumed to be due to iron deficiency (178), with the rest due to other conditions 
such as folate, vitamin B12 or vitamin A deficiencies, chronic inflammation, parasitic infections 
and inherited disorders. A pregnant woman is considered to be anaemic if her haemoglobin 
concentration during the first and third trimester of gestation is lower than 110 g/l
